article.title: Dave_Winer
article.paragraph: Dave Winer(born May 2, 1955 inBrooklyn,New York City) is anUnited StatesAmericansoftware developer, entrepreneur and writer inNew York City.cite webWinerDaveGetting back to New YorkScripting News2010-06-302010-06-20http://scripting.com/stories/2010/06/20/gettingBackToNewYork.htmlWiner is noted for his contributions tooutliners,scripting languagescripting,content management, andweb services, as well asbloggingandpodcasting. He is the founder of the software companiesLiving Videotext,Userland Softwareand Small Picture Inc.,cite newshttp://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-57576134-93/dave-winer-debuts-classic-little-outliner/Dave Winer debuts 'classic' Little OutlinerCNETMarch 25, 2013April 3, 2013a former contributing editor for the Web magazineHotWired, the author of theScripting Newscite webhttp://scripting.com/Scripting NewsScripting.comDaveWinerblogweblog, a former research fellow atHarvard Law School, and current visiting scholar atNew York University's Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute.
article.heading: Family background and education
article.paragraph: Winer was born on May 2, 1955, inBrooklyn,New York City, the son of Eve Winer, Ph.D., a school psychologist, andLeon Winer, Ph.D., a former professor of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. Winer is also the grandnephew of German novelistArno Schmidtand a relative ofHedy Lamarr.cite webWinerDaveSpindler Speaks!DaveNet2009-06-101994-12-27http://www.scripting.com/davenet/1994/12/27/spindlerspeaks.htmlHe graduated from theBronx High School of Sciencein 1972.Dave Winer's Personal Website: Curriculum VitaeWiner received aBachelor of ArtsBAinMathematicsfromTulane UniversityinNew Orleansin 1976. In 1978 he received an MS inComputer Sciencefrom theUniversity of WisconsinMadison.
article.heading: Career
Early work in outliners
article.paragraph: In 1979 Dave Winer became an employee ofPersonal Software, where he worked on his own product idea named VisiText, which was his first attempt to build a commercial product around an "expand and collapse" outline displayCite newsSwaineMichaelMichael Swaine (author)Calling Apple's BluffDr. Dobb's2009-06-081991-09-01http://www.ddj.com/showArticle.jhtml?articleIDand which ultimately establishedoutlinersas a software product. In 1981 he left the company and foundedLiving Videotextto develop this still-unfinished product. The company was based inMountain View, CaliforniaMountain View,CaliforniaCA, and grew to more than 50 employees.

ThinkTank, which was based on VisiText, was released in 1983 forApple II seriesApple IIand was promoted as an "idea processor."Cite newsSandberg-DimentErik'First idea processor'New York Times2009-05-101983-05-17http://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/17/science/personal-computers-software-first-idea-processor.html?&pagewantedIt became the "first popular outline processor, the one that made the term generic."Cite newsSandberg-DimentErikNew Software for making note scribbling easierNew York Times2009-06-041986-04-01http://www.nytimes.com/1986/04/01/science/personal-computers-new-software-for-making-note-scribbling-easier.html?&pagewantedA ThinkTank release for theIBMPersonal computerPCfollowed in 1984, as well as releases for theMacintosh128K and 512K.cite news78JimBartimoMacintosh: Success and disappointmentInfoworldFebruary 25, 198532Ready, aTerminate and Stay ResidentRAM residentoutliner for theIBMPersonal computerPCreleased in 1985, was commercially successful but soon succumbed to the competingBorland SidekickSidekickproduct byBorland.cite webWinerDaveGet up, and do it againDaveNet2009-06-081995-04-12http://davenet.scripting.com/1995/04/12/getupanddoitagain.htmlyeshttps://web.archive.org/20110716022923/http://davenet.scripting.com/1995/04/12/getupanddoitagain.html16 July 2011MORE (application)MORE, released for Apple'sMacintoshin 1986, combined anoutlinerand apresentation program. It became "uncontested in the marketplace"cite webWinerDaveOutliners & ProgrammingUserland2008-08-15 1988http://davewiner.userland.com/outlinersProgrammingand won theMacUser (US edition)MacUser's Editor's Choice Award for "Best Product" in 1986.cite webEddy Awards 1986MacUser2009-05-191986http://macuser.zdnet.com/eddy96/history/eddy1986.htmlhttp://web.archive.org/web/20010214031321/http://macuser.zdnet.com/eddy96/history/eddy1986.html2001-02-14

In 1987, at the height of his company's success, Winer soldLiving VideotexttoSymantecCite newsDysonEstherCritical MassRelease 1.01987-07-092009-06-08http://downloads.oreilly.com/radar/r1/07-87.pdffor an undisclosed but substantial transfer of stockCite newsSoftware Units Plan to MergeNew York Times2009-06-041987-07-09http://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/business/company-news-software-units-plan-to-merge.html?pagewantedthat "made his fortune."Cite journal10520341811102–108BorsookPaulinaPaulina BorsookKeeping the faithUpsideNovember 1996Winer continued to work at Symantec's Living Videotext division, but after six months he left the company in pursuit of other challenges.
article.heading: Years at UserLand
article.paragraph: Winer foundedUserland Softwarein 1988and served as the company's CEO until 2002.

UserLand's original flagship product,Userland Software#FrontierFrontier, was a system-levelscripting languagescriptingenvironment for theMacintoshMac, Winer's pioneering weblog,Scripting News, takes its name from this early interest. Frontier was an outliner-based scripting language, echoing Winer's longstanding interest in outliners and anticipating code-folding editors of the late 1990s.Winer became interested in web publishing while helping automate the production process of the strikers' online newspaper during San Francisco'sSan Francisco newspaper strike of 1994newspaper strikeof November 1994,According toNewsweek, through this experience, he "revolutionized Net publishing."Cite news50 For The FutureNewsweek2009-05-101995-02-27http://www.newsweek.com/id/106555/output/printyeshttps://web.archive.org/20111018120302/http://www.newsweek.com/id/106555/output/print18 October 2011Winer subsequently shifted the company's focus to online publishing products, enthusiastically promoting and experimenting with these products while building his websites and developing new features. One of these products wasUserland Software#FrontierFrontier's NewsPage Suite of 1997, which supported the publication of Winer'sScripting Newsand was adopted by a handful of users who "began playing around with their own sites in the Scripting News vein."These users included notablyChris GulkerandJorn Barger, who envisagedbloggingas asocial networking servicenetworkedpractice among users of the software.Cite conferenceACM10.1145/1557914.1557962978-1-60558-486-7279–288AmmannRudolfJorn Barger, the NewsPage network and the emergence of the weblog communityProceedings of the 20th ACM conference on hypertext and hypermediaTorino, Italy2009-07-152009http://tawawa.org/ark/p/jorn-barger-community.html

In 1997 Winer was appointed advisor toSeybold Seminarsdue to his "pioneering work in web-based publishing systems."cite webThe Seybold InstituteSeybold Seminars2010-05-231997http://www.seyboldseminars.com/News/fellows.htmlhttp://web.archive.org/web/19971018032643/http://www.seyboldseminars.com/News/fellows.html1997-10-18Keen to enter the "competitive arena of high-end Web development,"Cite newsMorgensternDavidMacWeekFrontier blazing Internet trail2010-05-311998-06-26macweek.zdnet.com/1224-0627/nw_frontier.htmlyeshttps://web.archive.org/20030701201326/http://macweek.zdnet.com:80/1224-0627/nw_frontier.html1 July 2003Winer then came to collaborate withMicrosoftand jointly developed theXML-RPCprotocol. This led to the creation ofSimple Object Access ProtocolSOAP, which he co-authored withMicrosoft'sDon Box, Bob Atkinson, and Mohsen Al-Ghosein.

In December 1997, acting on the desire to "offer much more timely information,"Cite newsGillmorDanSmall portals prove that size mattersSan Jose Mercury News1998-12-062010-07-20http://www.cse.iitb.ac.in/~soumen/focus/DanGillmor19981206.htmWiner designed and implemented anXMLsyndication format for use on hisScripting Newsweblog,cite newshttp://tim.oreilly.com/pub/a/oreilly/tim/news/2005/09/30/what-is-web-20.html?pageBlogging and the Wisdom of CrowdsTim O'ReillyO'Reilly and Associates2005-09-302007-01-29yeshttps://web.archive.org/20060518113913/http://tim.oreilly.com:80/pub/a/oreilly/tim/news/2005/09/30/what-is-web-20.html?page18 May 2006cite webhttp://www.scripting.com/davenet/1997/12/15/scriptingNewsInXML.htmlScripting News in XMLWiner, Dave1997-12-15[[Scripting News]]2006-10-31thus making an early contribution to thehistory of web syndication technology. By December 2000, competing dialects ofRSSincluded several varieties ofNetscape's RSS, Winer's RSS 0.92, and anResource Description FrameworkRDF-based RSS 1.0. Winer continued to develop the branch of the RSS fork originating from RSS 0.92, releasing in 2002 a version called RSS 2.0.RSS 2.0 specificationWiner's advocacy of web syndication in general and RSS 2.0 in particular convinced many news organizations to syndicate their news content in that format.cite newsMargaretKaneshttp://news.cnet.com/2100-1032-993344.html Old data update tool gains new converts CNET News March 20, 2003 2007-01-26For example, in early 2002 theNew York Timesentered an agreement with UserLand to syndicate many of their articles in RSS 2.0 format.cite newshttp://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?cNYTimes.com Expands Its RSS Feeds to 27 Categories New York Times (press release) July 20, 2004 2007-01-26Winer resisted calls by technologists to have the shortcomings of RSS 2.0 improved. Instead, he froze the format and turned its ownership over toHarvard University.Cite newsFestaPaulDispute exposes bitter power struggle behind Web logsCNET News2003-08-04http://news.cnet.com/Battle-of-the-blog/2009-1032_3-5059006.html

With products and services based on UserLand'sUserland Software#FrontierFrontiersystem, Winer became a leader inbloggingtools from 1999 onwards,Cite bookGillmorDanWe the Media: Grassroots Journalism by the People, for the PeopleThe Read-Write Web2010-05-312004http://authorama.com/we-the-media-3.htmlas well as a "leading evangelist of weblogs."In 2000 Winer developed the Outline Processor Markup LanguageOPML, anXMLformat forOutline (summary)outlines, which originally served as the native file format forRadio UserLand'soutlinerapplication and has since been adopted for other uses, the most common being to exchange lists ofweb feedsbetween webfeed aggregators. UserLand was the first to add an "enclosure" tag in its RSS, modifying its blog software and its aggregator so that bloggers could easily link to an audio file (seepodcastingandhistory of podcasting).

In February 2002 Winer was named one of the "Top Ten Technology Innovators" byInfoWorld.cite webUdellJonTop ten technology innovators: Dave WinerInfoworld2009-05-132002-02-27http://www.infoworld.com/articles/fe/xml/02/03/04/020304fewiner.htmlhttp://web.archive.org/web/20041104022339/http://www.infoworld.com/articles/fe/xml/02/03/04/020304fewiner.html2004-11-04

In June 2002 Winer underwent life-savingcoronary artery bypass surgerybypass surgerycite newsAnd the winner is ...SteveGillmorJanuary 3, 2003May 2, 2012http://www.infoworld.com/print/9167InfoWorldto prevent a heart attack and as a consequence stepped down as CEO ofUserLand SoftwareUserLandshortly after.cite webWinerDaveAn untold story of UserLandScripting News2008-08-082007-03-12http://www.scripting.com/stories/2007/03/12/anUntoldStoryOfUserland.htmlHe remained the firm's majority shareholder, however, and claimed personal ownership ofWeblogs.com.
article.heading: Writer
article.paragraph: As "one of the most prolific content generators in Web history,"Cite news95ConeEdwardAlmost FamousWired2009-05-13May 2001http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/9.05/winer_pr.htmlWiner has enjoyed a long career as a writer and has come to be counted amongSilicon Valley's "most influential web voices."Cite newsJonesK. C.NowPublic Lists Silicon Valley's Most Influential Web VoicesInformation Week2009-05-112008-07-31http://www.informationweek.com/news/internet/social_network/showArticle.jhtml?articleID

Winer startedDaveNet,cite webhttp://scripting.com/davenetDaveNetScripting.comDAveWiner"a stream-of-consciousness newsletter distributed by e-mail"Cite newsMarkoffJohnAn Internet Critic Who Is Not Shy About Ruffling the Big Names in High TechnologyNew York Times2009-05-092001-04-09http://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/09/business/internet-critic-who-not-shy-about-ruffling-big-names-high-technology.html?secin November 1994Cite news35LappinToddDavenetWired2014-11-18May 1995http://archive.wired.com/wired/archive/3.05/scans.html?pgand maintained Web archives of the "goofy and informative"Cite newsNolanChrisTalk is CheapSan Jose Mercury NewsSan Jose1997-10-13800-word essays since January 1995,cite webWinerDaveWhat is an Agent?DaveNet2011-02-211995-01-02http://www.scripting.com/davenet/1995/01/02/whatisanagent.htmlwhich earned him aCool Site of the Dayaward in March 1995.cite webStill Cool ArchiveCool Site of the Day2011-02-24March 1995http://www.coolsiteoftheday.com/cgi-bin/stillcool.pl?monthFrom the start, the "Internet newsletter"Cite newsFinalB1EinsteinDavidWozniak chastises his Apple: Biggest blunder was not sharing its OSThe San Francisco ChronicleSan Francisco1995-08-29DaveNetwas widely read among industry leaders and analysts,Cite news1361–24MichalskiJerryWhat's a zine?Release 1.01995-06-23who experienced it as a "real community."Cite bookBrockmanJohnDigerati: Encounters with the Cyber EliteThe Lover2009-05-111996http://www.edge.org/documents/digerati/Winer.htmlDissatisfied with the quality of the coverage that theMac OSMacand, especially, his ownUserLand Software#FrontierFrontiersoftware received in the trade press, Winer sawDaveNetas an opportunity to "bypass"Cite bookGillmorDanWe the Media: Grassroots Journalism by the People, for the PeopleFrom Tom Paine to Blogs and Beyond2009-05-132004http://www.authorama.com/we-the-media-2.htmlthe conventional news channels of the software business. Satisfied with his success, he "reveled in the new direct email line he had established with his colleagues and peers, and in his ability to circumvent the media."Cite bookeBookCrown978-0-307-45138-550RosenbergScottSay Everything: How Blogging Began, What It's Becoming, and Why It MattersThe unedited voice of a person: Dave WinerNew York2009-06-16In the early years, Winer often usedDaveNetto vent his grievances againstApple IncApple's management, and as a consequence of his strident criticism came to be seen as "the most notorious of the disgruntled Apple developers."RedactedDaveNetcolumns were published weekly by the web magazineHotWiredbetween June 1995 and May 1996.DaveNetwas discontinued in 2004.

Winer'sScripting News,acclaimed as "one of the oldest blogs,"cite newsNew York Times2002-06-10 2011-01-22David F.GallagherA rift among bloggershttp://www.nytimes.com/2002/06/10/business/technology-a-rift-among-bloggers.html?pagewantedlaunched in February 1997cite webAmmannRudolfScripting News: Launched on 1 February 1997Tawawa2011-02-022010-03-27http://tawawa.org/ark/2010/3/27/scripting-news-launched-1-feb-1997.htmland earned him titles such as "protoblogger"Cite newsMitchellDanA Bubble Watcher Watches GoogleNew York Times2009-05-102006-12-02http://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/02/business/02online.html?_rand "forefather of blogging."cite webGilbertsonScottA DIY Data ManifestoWebmonkey2011-03-052011-02-03http://www.webmonkey.com/2011/02/take-back-the-tubes/Scripting Newsstarted as "a home for links, offhand observations, and ephemera"Cite bookeBookCrown978-0-307-45138-558RosenbergScottSay Everything: How Blogging Began, What It's Becoming, and Why It MattersThe unedited voice of a person: Dave WinerNew York2009-06-16and allowed Winer to mix "his roles as a widely read pundit and an ambitious entrepreneur."Cite bookeBookCrown978-0-307-45138-559RosenbergScottSay Everything: How Blogging Began, What It's Becoming, and Why It MattersThe unedited voice of a person: Dave WinerNew York2009-06-16Offering an "as-it-happened portrait of the work of writing software for the Web in the 1990s,"the site became an "established must-read for industry insiders."Scripting Newscontinues to be updated regularly.
article.heading: Berkman Fellow at Harvard
article.paragraph: Winer spent one year as a resident fellow at theHarvard Law School'sBerkman Center for Internet & Society, where he worked on using weblogs in education.cite newshttp://news.cnet.com/2008-1082-985714.htmlNewsmaker: Blogging comes to Harvard asPaul Festa[[CNET]]2003-02-252007-01-25While there, he launchedWeblogs at Harvard Law Schoolcite webWeblogs at Harvard Law SchoolHarvard Universityhttp://blogs.law.harvard.eduusing UserLand software,cite newsFebruary 28, 2003'Blog' expert hopes to bring trend to HarvardSam J.LinHarvard CrimsonCambridge, Mass.and held the firstBloggerConconferences. Winer's fellowship ended in June 2004.
article.heading: Visiting Scholar at New York University
article.paragraph: In 2010 Winer was appointed Visiting Scholar atNew York University's Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute.cite newsJayRosenDave Winer, Welcome to NYURebooting the News2010-01-142011-01-21http://rebootnews.com/2010/01/14/dave-winer-welcome-to-nyu-visiting-scholar-technical-adviser/
article.heading: Return to Outliners
article.paragraph: On December 19, 2012,What is Fargo?Winer co-founded (with Kyle Shank) Small Picture, Inc., a corporation which builds two outlining products, Little Outliner and Fargo.Little Outliner, an entry-level outliner designed to teach new users about outliners,Little Outliner press guidelaunched on March 25, 2013.Fargo, the company's "primary product",launched less than a month later, on April 17, 2013. Fargo is a browser-based outliner which stores the user's outlines in their Dropbox account. It is a free product; in the future, Small Picture may offer paid-for services to Fargo users.
article.heading: Projects and activities
24 Hours of Democracy
article.paragraph:
In February 1996, while working as a columnist forHotWired, Winer organized24 Hours of Democracydead linkJanuary 2014, an online protest against the recently passedCommunications Decency Act. As part of the protest, over 1,000 people, among themMicrosoftchairmanBill Gates, posted essays to the Web on the subject ofdemocracy,civil libertyandfreedom of speech.Cite news"24 Hours In Democracy" Protests Telecom Act Newsbytes 1996-02-22
Cite newsA18 Next Step on the Net The Washington Post 1996-02-26
article.heading: Edit This Page
article.paragraph: In December 1999, Winer became the "proprietor of a growing freeweblogblogservice"Cite bookeBookCrown978-0-307-45138-547–69 [67]RosenbergScottSay Everything: How Blogging Began, What It's Becoming, and Why It MattersThe unedited voice of a person: Dave WinerNew York2009-06-16at EditThisPage.com,Cite book1stNew Riders0-7357-1299-9StoneBizBlogging: Genius Strategies for Instant Web ContentNew York2002-09-118cite webWinerDaveEditThisPage.ComDaveNet2009-06-101999-12-08http://www.scripting.com/davenet/1999/12/08/editthispagecom.htmlhosting "approximately 20,000 sites"cite webWinerDaveHow to Make Money on the Internet v2.0DaveNet2009-06-102001-02-13http://www.scripting.com/davenet/2001/02/13/howToMakeMoneyOnTheInterne.htmlin February 2001. The service closed in December 2005.cite webKitchensSusan A.Bye bye, (free) Editthispage!20/20 Hindsight2009-06-102005-11-28http://www.2020hindsight.org/2005/11/28/bye-bye-free-editthispage/
article.heading: Podcasting
article.paragraph: Winer has been given "credit for the invention of the podcasting model."Cite newsChenBrian X.This Day In Tech - Podfather’ Adam Curry Launches Daily Source CodeWired2011-05-012004-08-13http://www.wired.com/thisdayintech/2009/08/dayintech_0813/Having received user requests forPodcastaudiobloggingfeatures since October 2000, especially fromAdam Curry,cite newsJodieNazehttp://www.itworld.com/nls_ecommercepodcast041027Podcasting: The latest buzzITworld.com October 27, 2004 2007-01-25cite webWinerDaveVirtual BandwidthDaveNet2009-06-122000-10-31http://davenet.scripting.com/2000/10/31/virtualBandwidth.htmlyeshttps://web.archive.org/20110716022928/http://davenet.scripting.com/2000/10/31/virtualBandwidth.html16 July 2011Winer decided to include new functionality inRSS0.92Winer, Dave, 2000-12-25RSS 0.92 Specificationby defining a new elementWiner, Dave, 2000-12-27Scripting News:Heads-up, I'm working on new features for RSS that build on 0.91. Calling it 0.92...called "enclosure,"cite webWinerDavePayloads for RSSThe Two-Way Web2009-06-122001-01-11http://www.thetwowayweb.com/payloadsforrsscite webUdellJonHypermedia: Why Now?O'Reilly2009-05-112005-03-18http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/network/2005/03/18/primetime.htmlCite newsFarivarCyrusNew Food for IPods: Audio by SubscriptionNew York Times2009-05-112004-10-28http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?reswhich would pass the address of a media file to the RSS aggregator. He demonstrated the RSS enclosure feature on January 11, 2001 by enclosing aGrateful Deadsong in hisScripting Newsweblog.Winer, Dave, 2001-01-11Scripting News:Tonight's song on the Grateful Dead audio weblog is Truckin...

Winer's weblogging product,Radio Userland, the program favored byAdam CurryCurry, had a built-in aggregator and thus provided both the "send" and "receive" components of what was then calledPodcastaudioblogging.Curry, Adam, 2002-10-21UserNum 1014:Cool to hear my own audio-blog...Gilchrist, Harold 2002-10-27 ''Audioblog/Mobileblogging Newsthis morning I'm experimenting with producing an audioblogging show...In July 2003 Winer challenged other aggregator developers to provide support for enclosures.cite webWiner Dave How to support enclosures in aggregators RSS 2.0 at Harvard Law 2009-06-12 2003-07-18 http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/rss/enclosuresAggregators.html
In October 2003,Kevin Marksdemonstrated a script to download RSS enclosures and pass them toiTunesfor transfer to aniPod.cite webMarks Kevin Bloggercon live video Epeus' epigone 2009-06-12 2003-10-04 http://epeus.blogspot.com/2003/10/bloggercon-live-video.html
Curry then offered an RSS-to-iPod scriptcite webCurry Adam RSS2iPod Adam Curry's Weblog 2009-06-12 2003-10-12 http://radio.weblogs.com/0001014/2003/10/12.html#a4604
that movedMP3files fromRadio UserLandtoiTunes. The term "podcasting" was suggested byBen Hammersleyin February 2004.Cite newsHammersleyBenAudible revolutionThe Guardian2009-06-122004-02-12http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2004/feb/12/broadcasting.digitalmedia

Winer also has an occasional podcast, Morning Coffee Notes,cite webWinerDave An occasional podcast Morning Coffee Notes 2009-06-12 http://morningcoffeenotes.com/
which has featured guests such asDoc Searls,Mike Kowalchik,Jason Calacanis,Steve Gillmor,Peter Rojas,Cecile Andrews,Adam Curry,Betsy Devineand others.
article.heading: BloggerCon
article.paragraph: mainBloggerConBloggerCon is a user-focused conference for the blogger community. BloggerCon I (October 2003) and II (April 2004), were organized by Dave Winer and friends at Harvard Law School's Berkman Center for the Internet and Society in Cambridge, Mass. BloggerCon III met atStanford Law Schoolon November 6, 2004.Cite newsKramerStaci DTwo Cities, Two Gatherings for Two Kinds of Content CreatorsOnline Journalism Review2008-08-172004-11-19http://www.ojr.org/ojr/stories/041119kramer/print.htm
article.heading: Weblogs.com
article.paragraph: mainWeblogs.comWeblogs.com provided a freeping-serverused by manyweblogbloggingapplications, as well as free hosting to many bloggers. After leavingUserland SoftwareUserland, Winer claimed personal ownership of the site, and in mid-June 2004 he shut down its free blog-hosting service, citing lack of resources and personal problems.cite webLordTimothyHosting Service Closes 3000 Blogs Without NoticeSlashdot2009-05-112004-06-15http://slashdot.org/articles/04/06/15/2354258.shtml?tidcite webLord TimothySlashback: Munich, Harlan, AlacritySlashdot2009-05-112005-06-17http://developers.slashdot.org/article.pl?sidA swift and orderly migration off Winer's server was facilitated byRogers Cadenhead,Cite newsKramerStaci DWeblogs.com Rises From the FlamesWired2008-08-082004-06-23http://www.wired.com/print/culture/lifestyle/news/2004/06/63953whom Winer then hired to port the server to a more stable platform.Cite newsCaloreMichaelBest Blogfights of 2006Wired2008-08-082007-03-01http://www.wired.com/print/techbiz/it/news/2007/01/72396In October, 2005,VeriSignbought the Weblogs.comPing blogping-serverfrom Winer and promised that its free services would remain free. Thepodcasting-related web site audio.weblogs.com was also included in the $2.3 million deal.Cite newsNaraine Ryan VeriSign Acquires Dave Winer's Weblogs.com eWeek.com 2009-05-08 2005-10-06 http://www.eweek.com/index2.php?optiondead linkJanuary 2014
article.heading: Share your OPML
article.paragraph: Winer opened his self-described "commons for sharing outlines, feeds, and taxonomy" in May 2006.cite webArringtonMichael Share Your OPMLTechCrunch2009-06-082006-05-07http://www.techcrunch.com/2006/05/07/share-your-opml/The site allowed users to publish and syndicateblogrollsandfeed aggregatoraggregatorsubscriptions usingOPML.Cite bookO'Reilly Media, Inc.978-0-596-52822-5BellingerAmyGetting Acquainted with OPMLSebastopol, CA2006-10-175–7Winer suspended its service in January 2008.cite webWinerDaveShare.opml.org, retiredScripting News2009-06-082008-01-23http://www.scripting.com/stories/2008/01/23/shareopmlorgRetired.html
article.heading: Rebooting the News
article.paragraph: Since 2009, Winer has collaborated withNew York University's associate professor of journalismJay RosenonRebooting the News, a weeklypodcaston technology and innovation in journalism.cite webWindsorTimRebooting The News: Dave Winer and Jay Rosen on saving journalism» Nieman Journalism Lab2011-01-222009-04-20http://www.niemanlab.org/2009/04/rebooting-the-news-dave-winer-and-jay-rosen-talk-about-saving-journalism/It was announced on July 1, 2011 that the show would be on break, as NYU itself was, from June to September. However, no new episodes have been released since, making show #94 released on May 23, 2011 the last.cite webRosenJayWe’re on summer break for a bit» Rebooting the News2012-12-012011-07-01http://rebootnews.wordpress.com/2011/07/01/were-on-summer-break-for-a-bit/
article.heading: References
External links
